data.title: Songs of the South: James Brown & Tina Turner

data.text:
James Brown and Tina Turner showcased the vibrant culture and heritage of the American Black South throughout their successful careers in entertainment.

An Opinion Piece.

By: Ian L. Courts

Two figures who are closely associated with Black American music during the 20th Century are James Brown, also known as the Godfather of Soul, and Tina Turner, who is often referred to as the Queen of Rock & Roll. Both James Brown and Tina Turner embody the essence of the "Song of the Black South" through their origins, distinctive voices, and exceptional success in their recording careers.

James Brown and Tina Turner lived and performed in an American South that was blatantly racist, its institutions anti-Black, and its citizens segregated. Black men and women endured abuse, second-class citizenship, apartheid, and racial violence both physically and mentally. In the mid-20th Century, many Black Americans in the South lived in rural towns and worked in various industries such as farming, manufacturing, mills, and service jobs. These jobs required strength, resilience, and endurance to survive the long hours and harsh working conditions for minimal pay. Music became an outlet for release and relief for Black Southerners, and "soul music" in particular gave a glimpse into the life they endured in America. James Brown and Tina Turner served as cultural ambassadors and musical evangelists, representing the struggles, triumphs, and perseverance of Black American Southerners during the mid-20th century.

James Joseph Brown

Born in Barnwell, South Carolina in 1933, James Brown grew up in rural Georgia. He started singing in gospel circuits in Freewill Baptist and Pentecostal spaces. It was in church that he developed his passionate singing and ecstatic performance style, influenced by the exuberant worship expression of Southern rural Baptist and Pentecostal-Holiness churches.

During the 1950s, James commenced his music career by leading the Famous Flames as the lead singer and gained worldwide fame. Some of James' earliest hits comprise “Please, Please, Please”, “Try Me”, “I Got You (I Feel Good)”, and “It's a Man’s World”. James's songs offered a peek into the agony, perseverance, inherent struggles, and blues of Black men in the American South during the 50s and 60s. James sang about love, passion, loss, depression, excitement, sex, money, confidence, and, most importantly, the BLACKNESS that he and several other Black men experienced and lived in the South at that time. James Brown epitomized the spirit of the Black man, enabling the multifaceted creativity of Black men to thrive through his dance, wails, hollers, flamboyant clothing, and performances. This allowed Black men to be admired, respected and appreciated not only by the Black community but by America as a whole.

James Brown's concerts were attended by both White and Black Americans, and his music reached the top of the Billboard charts. He earned the nickname "Hardest Working Man in Show Business" due to his extensive schedule of concerts, tours, and performances, which totaled hundreds of days each year. Brown's influence was significant in bringing Black Southern Culture into the mainstream and making it an integral part of America's entertainment industry and overall culture.

Tina Turner

Anna Mae Bullock, known to the world as Tina Turner was born in Nutbush, Tennessee in 1939. Little Ann as she was known then, grew up singing in her rural Black Baptist Church, where she developed her passionate and expressive voice and singing style. In the 1950s, she moved to St. Louis and started performing in small Black venues and nightclubs. It wasn’t until she caught the eye of Ike Turner from the Kings of Rhythm that she gained nationwide recognition.

Tina Turner rose to fame in the 1960s alongside her then-husband Ike Turner, captivating Black audiences across the United States and European crowds internationally. With hits like "Proud Mary," "Sweet Rhode Island Red," "It's Gonna Work Out Fine," "Nutbush City Limits," and "River Deep Mountain High," Tina's voice embodied the strength, grit, and resilience of Black women in the American South. Despite facing abandonment, discrimination, misogyny, physical abuse, racism, and the challenges of Black womanhood, Tina's powerful and raw voice mesmerized audiences and remains unmatched by any contemporary performer.

For five decades, Tina's concerts and tours filled stadiums, arenas, and musical concert halls. She inspired people of all genders, sexual orientations, races, and cultures by embodying victory and rising like a phoenix from the pain and ashes beneath her. Tina's music brought the Song of the Black American South to the mainstream, increasing appreciation and recognition for Black Southern cultural expression and musical tradition.

James Brown and Tina Turner were pioneers for generations of Black musicians and entertainers. Their music embodied the reality of Black life in the rural American South during the mid-20th century. Their success indirectly manifested Black resilience and creative genius despite societal pressures against them.

To end on a positive note, I want to share two incredible performances by James Brown and Tina Turner. They both sang "Please, Please, Please (Don't Go)" one year apart, with Brown performing in 1964 and Turner in 1965. These performances showcase their raw power and Black identity, making them legendary. Take a moment to listen and appreciate a piece of Black Southern history and musical genius.
